item.title: Password Generator [AS3] [Please Delete]
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

#!/usr/bin/perl
use strict;
use warnings;

# All printable ascii characters
my @chars = (32..126);
my $num_chars = @chars;

# Passwords must be 50 chars long, unless specified otherwise
my $length=$ARGV[0] || 50;

while (1) {
        my $password;
        foreach (1..$length) {
                $password .= chr($chars[int(rand($num_chars))]);
        }

        # Password must have lower, upper, numeric, and 'other'
        if (    $password =~ /[a-z]/
            and $password =~ /[A-Z]/
            and $password =~ /[0-9]/
            and $password =~ /[^a-zA-Z0-9]/ ) {
                print $password, "\n";
                exit;
        }
}

I didn’t write it, mind you.

Read full topic

item.title: Password Generator [AS3] [Please Delete]
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

T4_:

EDIT: oh you’re trying to accomplish something like a key-ring. Isn’t that sort of insecure considering if someone were to get a hold of the ring, they’d have all the passwords on that ring?

Yes, only if they get hold of all the sites you have used the same masterpassword, you get their login name and you get the length of the password. But why should anyone get hold of the your original password? And I don’t see anyway to generate the password without lots of time and a supercomputer.

My goal was to make something between LastPass who stores all the password, and just make a random string.

Read full topic

item.title: Password Generator [AS3] [Please Delete]
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

Ew, actionscript.

	private static String generatePassword(int length) {
		StringBuilder password = new StringBuilder();
		for(int i = 0; i < length; i++)
			password.append(String.valueOf((char) (33 + (int) (Math.random() * (126 - 33) + 1))));
		return password.toString();
	}

Any why wouldn’t you just use something like this?

EDIT: oh you’re trying to accomplish something like a key-ring. Isn’t that sort of insecure considering if someone were to get a hold of the ring, they’d have all the passwords on that ring?

Read full topic

@bowserjr2 wrote:

Anyways, it could be changed.
